body:
Good catch!

Thanks for bringing this to our attention. üëç
...except that.... well, none of the modules in JUnit actually rely on the `@API Guardian` at runtime.

In fact, this _issue_ just made me realize that the dependency metadata (i.e., Maven POM) is actually incorrect for all artifacts that we just released in JUnit 5.0 GA.

For example: https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/junit/jupiter/junit-jupiter-api/5.0.0/junit-jupiter-api-5.0.0.pom

`apiguardian-api` should **not** be listed as a `compile` dependency.
If there is no runtime access, you could mark it as `compileOnly`.  The same approach could be taken for the nullability annotations in #358.

@mkobit, yep exactly!

That's what I'm going to have us do for the next release. üòâ

issue.title: Remove compile dependency on apiguardian-api in Maven POMs

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: ‚úÖ The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

Commit 77c0f9a5002c52ca0f9d363a77a674137f5ae66e accidentally introduced a Maven `compile` scope dependency on the `apiguardian-api` artifact in all published JUnit artifacts; whereas, the dependency should **ideally** be listed as `optional` in the generated Maven POMs since there are in fact zero runtime dependencies on `@API` within published JUnit artifacts.

## Related Issues

- https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-178888
- #1064 
- #1105

## Deliverables

- [x] Remove `compile` dependency on `apiguardian-api` in generated Maven POMs.
- [x] Consider including an `optional` dependency on `apiguardian-api` in generated Maven POMs.
  - AFAIK, it is not possible to generate an `optional` dependency with the standard Gradle infrastructure. For that we will likely have to use a third-party tool such as the [propdeps-plugin](https://github.com/spring-gradle-plugins/propdeps-plugin) from the Spring team.
- ‚ùå Consider backporting this change to `1.0.1`, `5.0.1`, and `4.12.0.1` releases.
  - Team decision: do not backport unless such branches are created due to other needs.

body:
**Update**

Since there are no runtime dependencies on `apiguardian-api`, I am repurposing this issue to document that fact in the User Guide.

#1065 will _fix_ the dependency scope in the generated Maven POMs.

rename.from: Update 'Dependency Diagram' to reflect dependency on apiguardian-api
rename.to: Document optional dependency on apiguardian-api in the User Guide

body: This issue is _blocked_ until #1065 is resolved.

rename.from: Document optional dependency on apiguardian-api in the User Guide
rename.to: Document optional dependency on apiguardian-api in User Guide

body: Thanks for quick response and explanation in YouTrack :).

@mkobit 

> If there is no runtime access, you could mark it as `compileOnly`.  The same approach could be taken for the nullability annotations in #358.

The problem with `compileOnly` in Gradle is that the dependency is no longer listed at all in the generated Maven POMs; whereas, we actually want it to show up as an `optional` dependency. üòû 

Note, however, that I'm aware of a solution to that and will address that in #1065.

> The problem with `compileOnly` in Gradle is that the dependency is no longer listed at all in the generated Maven POMs; whereas, we actually want it to show up as an `optional` dependency. üòû

Do we want this because we want to be able to perform API-related analysis on both source code and compiled bytecode using these annotations, for example to check that no third party code uses internal details?

> Do we want this because we want to be able to perform API-related analysis on both source code and compiled bytecode using these annotations, for example to check that no third party code uses internal details?

Yes.

That's one of the primary objectives of the `@API Guardian` project... even if the project home page currently has _zero_ documentation listing the objectives. üòâ

FWIW, the (currently internal) [ApiReportGenerator](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/platform-tests/src/test/java/org/junit/api/tools/ApiReportGenerator.java) already performs analysis on byte code.

> FWIW, the (currently internal) ApiReportGenerator already performs analysis on byte code.

Oh, cool! For some reason, I thought ApiReportGenerator only worked on source code. :P
